title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@posit.co. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Efficient Model Functions for Bagging
text: goal baguette provide efficient functions bagging (aka bootstrap aggregating) ensemble models. model objects produced baguette kept smaller otherwise two operations: butcher package used remove object elements crucial using models. example, models contain copies training set model residuals created. removed save space. ensembles whose base models use formula method, built-redundancy model identical terms object. However, one takes separate space memory can quite large many predictors. baguette package solves problem replacing terms object object first model ensemble. Since terms objects modified, get functional capabilities using far less memory save ensemble.

title: Efficient Model Functions for Bagging

title: Efficient Model Functions for Bagging
text: baguette package provides engines models following table.

title: Efficient Model Functions for Bagging
text: Let’s build bagged decision tree model predict continuous outcome. models also return aggregated variable importance scores.
code: library(baguette)  bag_tree() %>%    set_engine("rpart") # C5.0 is also available here #> Bagged Decision Tree Model Specification (unknown mode) #>  #> Main Arguments: #>   cost_complexity = 0 #>   min_n = 2 #>  #> Computational engine: rpart  set.seed(123) bag_cars <-    bag_tree() %>%    set_engine("rpart", times = 25) %>% # 25 ensemble members    set_mode("regression") %>%    fit(mpg ~ ., data = mtcars)  bag_cars #> parsnip model object #>  #> Bagged CART (regression with 25 members) #>  #> Variable importance scores include: #>  #> # A tibble: 10 × 4 #>    term  value std.error  used #>    <chr> <dbl>     <dbl> <int> #>  1 disp  905.       51.9    25 #>  2 wt    889.       56.8    25 #>  3 hp    814.       48.7    25 #>  4 cyl   581.       42.9    25 #>  5 drat  540.       54.1    25 #>  6 qsec  281.       53.2    25 #>  7 vs    150.       51.2    20 #>  8 carb   84.4      30.6    25 #>  9 gear   80.0      35.8    23 #> 10 am     51.5      22.9    18

title: Bagging functions — bagger
text: General suite bagging functions several models.

title: Bagging functions — bagger
code: bagger(x, ...)  # Default S3 method bagger(x, ...)  # S3 method for class 'data.frame' bagger(   x,   y,   weights = NULL,   base_model = "CART",   times = 11L,   control = control_bag(),   cost = NULL,   ... )  # S3 method for class 'matrix' bagger(   x,   y,   weights = NULL,   base_model = "CART",   times = 11L,   control = control_bag(),   cost = NULL,   ... )  # S3 method for class 'formula' bagger(   formula,   data,   weights = NULL,   base_model = "CART",   times = 11L,   control = control_bag(),   cost = NULL,   ... )  # S3 method for class 'recipe' bagger(   x,   data,   base_model = "CART",   times = 11L,   control = control_bag(),   cost = NULL,   ... )

title: Bagging functions — bagger
text: x data frame, matrix, recipe (depending method used). ... Optional arguments pass base model function. y numeric factor vector outcomes. Categorical outcomes (.e classes) represented factors, integers. weights numeric vector non-negative case weights. values used bootstrap resampling. base_model single character value model bagged. Possible values "CART", "MARS", "nnet", "C5.0" (classification ). times single integer greater 1 maximum number bootstrap samples/ensemble members (model fits might fail). control list options generated control_bag(). cost non-negative scale (two class problems) square cost matrix. formula object class "formula" (one can coerced class): symbolic description model fitted. Note package support multivariate outcomes , predictors factors, dummy variables created unless underlying model function. data data frame containing variables used formula recipe.

title: Bagging functions — bagger
text: bagger() fits separate models bootstrap samples. prediction function model object encoded R expression original model object discarded. making predictions, prediction formula evaluated new data aggregated using mean. Variable importance scores calculated using implementations package. requested, results tibble column names term (predictor), value (importance score), used (percentage times variable prediction equation). models can fit parallel using future package. enable parallelism, use future::plan() function declare computations distributed. Note almost certainly multiply memory requirements required fit models. neural networks, variable importance calculated using method Garson described Gevrey et al (2003)

title: Bagging functions — bagger
text: Gevrey, M., Dimopoulos, ., Lek, S. (2003). Review comparison methods study contribution variables artificial neural network models. Ecological Modelling, 160(3), 249-264.

title: Bagging functions — bagger
code: if (rlang::is_installed(c("recipes", "modeldata"))) {   library(recipes)   library(dplyr)    data(biomass, package = "modeldata")    biomass_tr <-     biomass %>%     dplyr::filter(dataset == "Training") %>%     dplyr::select(-dataset, -sample)    biomass_te <-     biomass %>%     dplyr::filter(dataset == "Testing") %>%     dplyr::select(-dataset, -sample)    # ------------------------------------------------------------------------------    ctrl <- control_bag(var_imp = TRUE)    # ------------------------------------------------------------------------------    # `times` is low to make the examples run faster     set.seed(7687)   cart_bag <- bagger(x = biomass_tr[, -6], y = biomass_tr$HHV,                      base_model = "CART", times = 5, control = ctrl)   cart_bag    # ------------------------------------------------------------------------------   # Other interfaces    # Recipes can be used   biomass_rec <-     recipe(HHV ~ ., data = biomass_tr) %>%     step_pca(all_predictors())    set.seed(7687)   cart_pca_bag <- bagger(biomass_rec, data = biomass_tr, base_model = "CART",                          times = 5, control = ctrl)    cart_pca_bag } #> Loading required package: dplyr #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union #>  #> Attaching package: ‘recipes’ #> The following object is masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     step #> Bagged CART (regression with 5 members) #>  #> Variable importance scores include: #>  #> # A tibble: 5 × 4 #>   term  value std.error  used #>   <chr> <dbl>     <dbl> <int> #> 1 PC2   4500.     245.      5 #> 2 PC1   3559.     156.      5 #> 3 PC3   1107.     210.      5 #> 4 PC5    648.     137.      5 #> 5 PC4    468.      71.6     5 #>

Controlling the bagging process — control_bag
text: control_bag() can set options ancillary aspects bagging process.

title: Controlling the bagging process — control_bag
code: control_bag(   var_imp = TRUE,   allow_parallel = TRUE,   sampling = "none",   reduce = TRUE,   extract = NULL )

title: Controlling the bagging process — control_bag
text: var_imp single logical: variable importance scores calculated? allow_parallel single logical: model fits done parallel (even parallel plan() created)? sampling Either "none" "". classification . training data, bootstrapping, sampled within class (replacement) size smallest class. reduce models modified reduce size disk? extract function (NULL) can extract model-related aspects ensemble member. See Details example .

title: Controlling the bagging process — control_bag
text: list.

title: Controlling the bagging process — control_bag
text: arbitrary item can saved model object (including model object ) using extract argument, function arguments x (model object), .... results function saved list column called extras (see example ).

title: Controlling the bagging process — control_bag
code: # Extracting model components  num_term_nodes <- function(x, ...) {   tibble::tibble(num_nodes = sum(x$frame$var == "<leaf>")) }  set.seed(7687) with_extras <- bagger(mpg ~ ., data = mtcars,                       base_model = "CART", times = 5,                       control = control_bag(extract = num_term_nodes))  dplyr::bind_rows(with_extras$model_df$extras) #> # A tibble: 5 × 1 #>   num_nodes #>       <int> #> 1         3 #> 2         3 #> 3         3 #> 4         3 #> 5         2

title: Predictions from a bagged model — predict.bagger
code: data(airquality)  set.seed(7687) cart_bag <- bagger(Ozone ~ ., data = airquality, base_model = "CART", times = 5) predict(cart_bag, new_data = airquality[, -1]) #> # A tibble: 153 × 1 #>    .pred #>    <dbl> #>  1  29.9 #>  2  20.5 #>  3  17.0 #>  4  22.3 #>  5  14.0 #>  6  18.7 #>  7  23.6 #>  8  17.4 #>  9  12.2 #> 10  23.5 #> # ℹ 143 more rows

title: Obtain variable importance scores — var_imp.bagger
text: tibble columns term (predictor), value (mean importance score), std.error (standard error), used (occurrences predictors).

title: Obtain variable importance scores — var_imp.bagger
text: baguette can compute different variable importance scores model ensemble. var_imp() function returns average importance score model. Additionally, function returns number times predictor included final prediction equation. Specific methods used models : CART: model accumulates improvement model occurs predictor used split. values taken form rpart object. See rpart::rpart.object(). MARS: MARS models include backwards elimination feature selection routine looks reductions generalized cross-validation (GCV) estimate error. earth() function tracks changes model statistics, GCV, predictor accumulates reduction statistic predictor's feature added model. total reduction used variable importance measure. predictor never used MARS basis functions final model (pruning), importance value zero. baguette wraps earth::evimp(). C5.0: C5.0 measures predictor importance determining percentage training set samples fall terminal nodes split. example, predictor first split automatically importance measurement 100 percent since samples affected split. predictors may used frequently splits, terminal nodes cover handful training set samples, importance scores may close zero. Note value column average importance scores form model. divisor average (corresponding standard error) number models (opposed number models used predictor). means importance scores predictor used model implicit zero importance.
